text: people were really sick and tired of
feeling disposable and we did not want
to feel disposable anymore and really
truly the turning point was just having
the information and having the resources
to do it
[Music]
i was a barista for about six years ever
since high school i truly didn't think
of myself as a career person
um i was just gonna work in food service
until i figured something else out
and then honestly
organizing kind of hit me like a truck
there's a like a colloquial term that's
barista hopping where you go from one
coffee shop to the next thinking it's
going to be better but it ends up being
about the same
it was getting to a point where i was
about at the end of my food service rope
um it had just been a very long time i
just wanted something that didn't make
me feel like i had
to rest for three days after one shift
[Music]
i think the turning point really came
just out of being exhausted
from working through the pandemic and
being considered disposable workers
while also at the same time society was
showing us that we were essential
workers because we were seeing hundreds
of people a day and public facing
having to fight people on
wearing masks and then being treated
rather poorly people were really sick
and tired of feeling disposable and we
did not want to feel disposable anymore
when i first heard about a union it was
through
my roommate she just kind of called me
one morning and was like hey what if you
unionized pavement and i said i don't
know what that means um tell me more
[Music]
being in a union essentially looks like
all of your co-workers just coming
together to support each other um and
then there's a lot more on like a
technical level that happens such as
like you now literally have 50 of the
say in your working terms and conditions
which is massive and it's just a legally
enforceable process that makes it so
yes you're coming together and acting
collectively
but there's also some accountability
from management and there are certain
things in place that they have to follow
they want to change anything
they can't do it without bargaining with
you first
when we had issues with management we
would go to them we would ask them to do
something about the problems we were
facing it was generally met with empty
promises
and we just wanted there to be something
that helped them accountable to what we
were asking for we were fighting a lot
for
just mostly having a say in our working
terms and conditions and that was
ranging from
scheduling to
pay is part of it
another part is just cause and
discipline
because in the united states you're an
at-will employee
so you can be fired for any reason
except
unless it's based in discrimination and
even then the burden of proof is on the
worker so we really wanted something set
in place of if you're going to be fired
there's going to be all of these steps
before and you're going to be very aware
of what is happening and you have a
grievance procedure along the way
i don't really think that we were that
afraid of being fired because the night
before we were actually in my apartment
that night ended up turning into all of
us rallying around if one person gets
fired we are turning off the toasters
we're walking out
we're not standing for it it was just a
really beautiful moment of solidarity um
i've
i've never felt so much support in one
room before and
it was just a really great energizing
wonderful moment to go into the next day
with which was
it was a big day it was a very chaotic
and energy-filled day
the next morning we handed the demand
letter to um management and
i
think that they were in shock um
honestly uh because you didn't really
hear about coffee shops organizing it
wasn't like
an industry that was thought of as one
that you organize um
so i think everyone was just kind of
like wow like this is actually happening
and they decided to voluntarily
recognize us which was unheard of i
remember an organizer at the time saying
that he would jump off a roof if that
happened because it was so unheard of
for this to happen so the fact that it
did floored us from there we were a
union and now we are in a contract fight
i think young people um specifically are
really energized by this movement
because it just seemed really kind of
hopeless honestly like especially when
the pandemic hit just the system is not
set up for us i think because it's so
tangible and so possible that's why it's
really taken off um it's something that
we can actively do
to change our working terms and
conditions and therefore
our life trajectories i never expected
to be here but i am so grateful that i
